Award.AwardTitle: WORKSHOP: New Horizons in Conflict System Analysis: Applications to the Middle East, Fall, 2010.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
It goes without saying that the Middle East conflict system is one of the world's most important and intractable problem areas, with consequences that ripple across the global system. At a time when academics in political science have been advocating multi-method research approaches that are strongly rooted in theory, this workshop brings together a variety of political science and social science approaches to social conflict and political conflict to examine the ongoing conflict system of the Middle East.

The workshop melds together academic approaches, methods and findings with policy oriented needs. It brings together conflict scholars, primarily from political science, applying a range of advanced, rigorous analytic and data gathering techniques, to address the single empirical domain of the contemporary Middle East conflict system. This multidisciplinary workshop demonstrates the complementarity between formal approaches and various empirical mtehods, and also notes the relevance of scholarly research to policy questions.

With regards to broader impacts, the results of the workshop will be of interest to policy makers dealing with conflict situations. In addition, a number of graduate students are invited to the workshop. They will have an opportunity to interact with the other participants as well as observe the development and use of multidisciplinary and multi-method approaches. It is hoped that these experiences will influence their later work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It goes without saying that the Middle East conflict system is one of the world’s most important and intractable problem areas, with consequences that ripple across the global system. And, at a time when academics in political science have been advocating multi-method approaches to research and the bringing together of basic research and policy-oriented research, we held a three-day conference which brought together conflict scholars, primarily from Political Science, applying a range of advanced, rigorous analytic and data gathering techniques, to address the single empirical domain of the contemporary Middle East conflict system (primarily focusing on Israel’s internal and external conflicts). Analytic approaches from several other disciplines were also represented, including network analysis (Sociology), GIS [geographic information system] techniques (Geography), and identity-based analyses to social conflict (Linguistics, Anthropology, Geography).  As proposed, the conference proved to be a significant component in the melding of academic approaches, methods, and findings, with policy oriented needs.

 

Merging the goals of intellectual merit and seeking broader impacts, the papers and discussions at the conference made both methodological and substantive contributions in a number of areas: (i) the crossing of multiple boundaries, such as the use of multi-method approaches to research; (ii) the melding of “qualitative” and “quantitative” research, in the sense of recognizing the causal complexity that exists in many areas of study; (iii) the use of research theory and findings across the sub-disciplines of political science as well as across the social sciences; (iv) crossing levels of analysis for a fuller integration of domestic (internal) and international (external) factors and contexts; (v) and bringing research findings to bear on policy analysis. These were achieved through 13 papers delivered in seven sessions (plus a public talk on the last night of the conference). The full list of session topics, participants, and titles of the papers presented (along with abstracts of those papers), can be found on the conference website at: http://www.cas.sc.edu/Iis/NSF/index.html  Videos of the first six sessions, as well as the public lecture, are also available on the website. 

 

A morning workshop on the last day of the conference, along with the review of all of the papers by the PI’s, has convinced us that these papers provide the basis for an edited volume (as well as the possibility of a new chapter written by the three main session discussants). Proposals for an edited volume were prepared and circulated to several presses, with two high-quality presses showing interest. The proposed volume includes 10 chapters based on revisions of the papers presented at the conference, plus an introductory chapter by Starr and Dubinsky, and a concluding chapter to be prepared by the three central discussants, each of whom discussed multiple papers. Based on the Sunday morning wrap-up workshop, the PI’s and participants found that several themes had emerged from the session discussions.
